posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: Hello! My team has designed and built an arm system that features 4 falcons on a (currently) 240:1 gear ratio designed to power our shoulder joint. In testing, we’ve encountered a couple of problems, it oscillates quite a bit despite chain being tensioned, and it being overall mechanically as sound as it can be at the moment(though were are looking to increase sprocket sizes for less working load on the chain, and for more teeth grab, as well as increasing the gear ratio, its mega fast right now…) though this is the case, we have been trying to tune it as best we can, after all, we are a week 1 competition so we are working with what we have for now. I’m wondering what the best control system would given this information. We have loads of experience with wpi pids, including trapezoidal motion profiled systems and systems that use feed forward gains using system identification. However, in this particular instance, we started by looking at CTRE PIDs which are new to us this year(we have used them on our swerve drive and telescoping arm) we did this because of their higher refresh rate of 1ms as well as their onboard motion magic. Though this is the case, I still could not get it to decelerate properly, my guess is poor tuning, but figuring out how to tune it “right” is difficult, despite following the documentation. I’m wondering if I should keep tuning using this, even if it will take a couple more hours to tune, but it has the benefit of having elegant acceleration and deceleration, or if I should throw in the towel and look towards something like a regular pid, or running something onboard the rio. Thank you!

posts.name: Weaver Goldman
posts.cooked: You may want to consider adding in a feedforward for controlling the arm. Since it has to counteract gravity, having a feedforward makes it easier to tune the feedback to perform as well as possible. WPILib docs has an advanced controls page with more information.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Henry_Mahnke:

Hello! My team has designed and built an arm system that features 4 falcons on a (currently) 240:1 gear ratio designed to power our shoulder joint.

How did you decide on that number of falcons and gear ratio? For reference, in 2018 when we were lifting ourselves and 2 other robots, we used 3 775 pros. You have approximately 3 times the power.

You’re likely making the control problem harder by making the system faster and more powerful then it needs to be.

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: We used the jvn calculator, our system is designed to be overkill by a lot because we didn’t have the end effector finalized, there is about 650 inch pounds of force across our arm, so right now we are sitting at 13 ish amps on the motors right now

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Now I’m curious what the arm design is, because that still sounds WAY overkill, or that you miscalculated somewhere

posts.name: Henry Mahnke
posts.cooked: HAHA we have a telescoping arm on our pivot, our pivot sits 42 inches up right now(29 in our next iteration), and its a 2 stage telescope (3 stage in our next iteration) with a giga grabber on the end, the mass of that entire assembly is about 20 pounds, and the c.o.g is about 34 inches from pivot at max extension, which is where we spec’d the arm out at. But yeah, we are going to increase the gear ratio, and drop 2 motors in our next iteration. No need to run at 159 degrees per second at 13 amps on each motor LOL. Good learning experience though

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: ~30RPM for a 20lb arm (at 34" from pivot)?! sweet jeebus… yeah, definitely don’t need all that haha
